title: 105_hr2604
content: The Act may be cited as the "Religious Liberty and Charitable Donation Protection Act of 1997". Definitions are provided in Section 2. Section 548(d) of title 11, United States Code, is amended to define 'charitable contribution' as a donation made by a natural person consisting of a financial instrument or cash. Additionally, 'qualified religious or charitable entity or organization' is defined as entities described in specific sections of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. SEC. 3. Treatment of prepetition qualified charitable contributions. Section 548(a) of title 11, United States Code is amended to include provisions regarding the transfer of charitable contributions to qualified religious or charitable entities. The transfer of such contributions shall not be considered a covered transfer under certain conditions, such as when the contribution amount does not exceed 15 percent of the debtor's gross annual income. Section 548(a) of title 11, United States Code is amended to include provisions regarding the transfer of charitable contributions. The contribution made by a debtor exceeding the specified percentage of gross annual income is allowed if consistent with the debtor's charitable practices. Amendments to Section 544(b) and Section 546 of title 11 are made to align with these changes. The Code is amended in subsections (e), (f), and (g) to update references from "548(a)(2)" to "548(a)(1)(B)" and from "548(a)(1)" to "548(a)(1)(A)". SEC. 4. TREATMENT OF POST-PETITION CHARITABLE CONTRIBUTIONS. The curr_chunk discusses amendments to the United States Code regarding charitable contributions in bankruptcy cases. It limits the amount of charitable contributions to 15 percent of the debtor's gross income and prohibits courts from considering charitable contributions when determining case dismissal under section 707(b). The curr_chunk defines a charitable entity or organization as per section 548(d)(4) of the United States Code. The Act and its amendments apply to cases under title 11, US Code pending on or after enactment. The amendments do not limit the Religious Freedom Restoration Act of 1993.
